  • installation

Installation

Recommended installation →

  • use conda (through anaconda)
  • or pip (easy_install pip) to manage Python packages
    • create a virtualenv to bundle and isolate bundled packages (easy_install virtualenv virtualenvwrapper)
    • install matplotlib with pip in virtualenv

uh… or it's probably already installed for you as part of anaconda →

Matplotlib

matplotlib is a Python package / module for creating data visualizations. It can be used for… →

  • creating charts and graphs
  • animations
  • interactivity

It has two main modes

  • scripting mode - similar to giving commands to turtle
  • object oriented - build figures using objects
  • scripting mode is easier to start off with, object oriented mode is more powerful / flexible

Matplotlib Vocabulary

Jargon makes matplotlib a little intimidating, but this visual aid helps explain commonly used terms. Additionally, here are some definitions: →

  • Canvas - the object that actually draws everything to screen (you won't usually be working on this directly)
  • Figure - you can think of this as your entire visualization / diagram, including the axes, its title, etc.
  • Axes - basically your plotted data; there can be more than one Axes object in a figure (so you can a figure with multiple bar charts on it, for example)
  • Axis - the lines in your graph that specify the graph boundaries / limits, its tick marks, etc.

Basic Boilerplate Code

Using scripting mode (pyplot) all you have to do is:

  1. import matplotlib
  2. plot something
  3. then show it…

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# your code goes here

# display plot
plt.show()

If you're in a notebook, you can use the magic command %matplotlib inline to display your visualizations directly in your notebook.

(in this case, the explicit call to show is not needed, and the plot is displayed once cell is run)

plot

plot plots points or a line. It's flexible in terms of arguments passed in, but a common way of calling it is plt.plot(x, y, format):

  • x and y - list or numpy array
  • format - a string representing the color and line/marker style (see docs for details)

plot can also be called with more or less arguments:

  • with 2 arguments, first y values (x is generated automatically), and second format
  • more than 3 arguments, multiple plots
  • with keyword arguments, like color='#ff0000'

lim, ticks, label, titles

You can use the following functions to format and style the entire figure:

  • xticks, yticks - the values shown and associated with the x and y ticks
  • xlim, ylim - the boundaries of the figure, the length of the x and y axis
  • xlabel, ylabel - the label for the x and y axis
  • title - set the title of the figure

An Entire Example

Setup…


import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

Some data…


x = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
y = [0, 2, 4, 9, 16]
x2 = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
y2 = [4, 5, 6, 7, 8]

plot Example Continued

Plot a dashed red line and a solid blue line


plt.plot(x, y, 'r--', x2, y2, 'b-')

Formatting…


plt.xticks([0, 2, 4], ['small', 'medium', 'large'])
plt.yticks([0, 16], ['not much', 'a lot'])

plt.xlabel('pizza size')
plt.ylabel('amount of toppings')

plt.xlim(-1, 5)
plt.ylim(0, 20)

Finally, display the figure…


plt.show()

bar

Documentation for the bar function… and a quick summary of its arguments plt.bar(x, h, w, align='center'): →

  1. the x coordinates of the left sides of the bars
  2. the heights of the bars
  3. the widths of the bars
  4. the keyword argument, align will allow you to align the bars to the right (edge) or center

Bar Chart Example

An example of a bar chart with labels: →

Start off with some data…


# labels
feels = ('üëç', 'üòí', 'üç†')

# y values
num_votes = [5, 3, 12]

# the x values (based on number of labels)
x = np.arange(len(feels))

Bar Chart Example Continued

Using data from previous slide…


plt.bar(x, num_votes, align='center', color='#aaddff')
plt.xticks(x, feels)
plt.ylim(0, 14)
plt.ylabel('Votes')
plt.xlabel('Feels')
plt.title('How U Feel Abt This Graph?')
plt.show()

Using a Dictionary

If your data were in a dictionary… here's how the previous program may look →


feels = {'üëç': 5, 'üòí':3, 'üç†':12}
plt.bar(np.arange(len(feels)), list(feels.values()), align='center', color='#aaddff')
plt.xticks(np.arange(len(feels)), list(feels.keys()))

plt.ylim(0, 14)
plt.ylabel('Votes')
plt.xlabel('Feels')
plt.title('How U Feel Abt This Graph?')
plt.show()
